awd_titl_txt: Design, Control and Optimization of Robotic Systems with Energy Regeneration
awd_abstract_narration:
Many industrial, consumer and medical products involve masses in motion. These motions are powered from energy sources, and always involve cycles of acceleration and deceleration. Conventional braking is a very inefficient method of deceleration because the object's energy is wasted as heat. In contrast, regeneration involves surplus energy capture and storage into the power supply. Regeneration engineering is advanced and visible in electric and hybrid vehicles, but its understanding and optimal utilization in mobile and industrial robotics remains a challenging area of research. The outcomes of this research have the potential for significant energy savings in industrial installations where many robots are in use. Mobile biomedical devices powered from electric energy sources such as wheelchairs, prostheses and exoskeletons are another target application of this research. Optimal energy utilization in these devices will translate into lighter units with a reduced need for frequent recharging. Impaired people wearing advanced regenerative prostheses will be able to extend the range of their daily activities, improving their quality of life.

This research will introduce a systematic treatment of general motion control problems with explicit consideration of bidirectional energy flow. The intellectual significance of the project is centered in its generality and broad applicability, which contrasts with the mostly case-oriented current literature on regenerative systems. The project focuses on the use of ultracapacitors as key elements of advanced regenerative systems. In comparison to batteries, ultracapacitors have very high power densities. This means that energy extraction and return can be achieved at fast rates. This feature affords great flexibility to alter a robot's dynamic behavior by means of control, in particular its mechanical impedance. Moreover, recent advances in graphene-based ultracapacitors have resulted in devices with energy densities approaching those of lithium-ion batteries. These advances have the potential for the elimination of batteries in certain mobile robotic systems, particularly in medical assistive devices. The project will establish a framework to design, control and optimize such systems. The project has three goals: 1. development of new approaches for modeling, control and design of robotic systems with advanced regenerative hardware such as ultracapacitors; 2. formulation and solution of fundamental energy-motion multi-objective optimization problems for the same; 3. bridging of theory and practice with a custom-built study robot.

por.por_cntn:
One major aspect of modern technology is related to objects which must move from rest to a maximum speed and back to rest, in cycles that define their operating requirements. Take for instance land transportation with cars and trains, industrial robots performing manufacturing operations, and even cutting-edge artificial limbs and other powered devices designed to assist or supplement human physical capability. They always start, move, stop and repeat the cycle. These operations involve energy consumption, and the proliferation of these systems has driven scientists and engineers to consider ways to improve efficiency as a means to reduce energy consumption. 
In this project, we have focused on robotic systems, particularly those powered from electric energy stored in batteries or using newer storage technologies such as supercapacitors. Both industrial and biomedical robots have been considered, and the benefits brought about by our research findings have been demonstrated in proof-of-concept experiments in each area. 
All-electric and hybrid vehicles incorporate energy efficiency as one of the major criteria for their design. An important aspect of this is a technology known as regenerative braking, where the energy associated with slowing down and stopping is harvested and stored for later reuse, rather than burning it all as friction in mechanical brakes. This component is a key contributor to the superior mileage per gallon available in hybrid vehicles in comparison with gasoline-only models. Likewise, all-electric vehicles can achieve their improved ranges thanks to optimal energy management systems that include regenerative modes.
Our project set out - and succeeded - in pursuing optimal energy management in robots. In summary, we sought out ways to design and operate (control) robots so that their energy efficiency would be maximized, while still complying with the tasks for which they were designed. We included regenerative operation and focused on the cutting-edge storage technology given by supercapacitors. These devices handle considerably more power per unit weight than batteries and are reliable and durable.
We demonstrated energy savings of up to 13% in an industrial robot executing pick-place operations. In the field of powered prostheses, we developed a prototype that incorporated our methodologies and findings in optimal energy management and control. Our regenerative prosthesis was tested with an amputee at the Cleveland Veterans Affairs hospital. The subject was able to walk naturally while receiving assistance from the prosthesis. Remarkably, our device does not need to be ever recharged, as it harvests enough energy derived from the natural surplus available in human walking. 
Our results have also shown promise for their applicability to unmanned air vehicles, which are electrically powered. As shown by recent research, their mass proliferation in package delivery systems could have a detrimental impact on the environment, unless optimal energy management is involved in their design and operation.
